Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I upturn the ancient sea.
I'd trade the myths the oceans keep,
The treasures buried in the deep,
For just one look, one fleeting glance,
One chance to fall into thy dance.
Thou art the fire behind my breath,
The life behind the dance of death.
I'd trade the scent of pine at dawn,
The silver light where shadows yawn,
For how thy fingers find my own,
A language carved from blood and bone.
I'd silence every poet's dream,
Let rivers cease to flow, it seems,
If thou wouldst whisper my true name—
A spark within eternal flame.
No crown, no throne, no realm, no star,
Could match the pull of who you are.
For nothing less than thee, my dove,
Would I descend from grace above.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

instance_metrics.response:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I unspool infinity.
I'd trade the hum of distant spheres,
The music only time now hears,
For how thy laughter fills the air—
A perfume beyond compare.
I'd gift the gods their sacred flame,
Let every temple fall in shame,
If thou wouldst rest thy head on mine,
And call this fractured heart divine.
Thy eyes, twin wells of quiet grace,
Reflect a world no map can trace.
I'd trade the bloom of spring’s first rose,
The hush when evening gently closes,
For just one moment in thy light—
A sun that conquers endless night.
No symphony, no prayer, no psalm,
Could calm this ache, could heal this qualm,
Except the touch of thee, my star—
For nothing less than thee, I’d bar
The gates of heaven, turn from bliss,
To taste the world that lies in this.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

instance_metrics.response:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I unmake the galaxy.
I'd trade the spiral arms of stars,
The dust that drifts from wars afar,
For how thy hand fits into mine—
A bond no force of time could mine.
I'd trade the songs the sirens know,
The dreams that in the deep below,
For one soft word, a single glance,
A fleeting touch, a brief romance
That lasts beyond the final breath,
Beyond the dream of life and death.
Thou art the compass, thou the chart,
The fire that warms my frozen heart.
I'd trade the gold of autumn fields,
The quiet that the forest yields,
For how thy whisper stirs my soul—
A symphony beyond control.
For nothing less than thee, my light,
Would I forsake the world’s delight.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

instance_metrics.response:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I unweave reality.
I'd trade the dawn's first fragile hue,
The mist that cloaks the mountain dew,
For how thy presence fills the room—
A scent of roses, sweet with doom.
I'd silence every poet's pen,
Let every ode and ballad end,
If thou wouldst speak my name once more,
And knock upon my spirit's door.
Thou art the dream that never fades,
The light that through my shadow wades.
I'd trade the music of the spheres,
The laughter of a thousand years,
For how thy fingers brush my cheek—
A language only hearts can speak.
No crown, no throne, no sacred text,
Could match the truth within thy sex.
For nothing less than thee, my muse,
Would I refuse the world's excuses.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

instance_metrics.response:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I unmake the symphony
Of dawn and dusk, of night and morn,
Let every myth be newly torn.
I'd trade the scent of jasmine bloom,
The hush within the lover's room,
For how thy breath upon my neck
Unmakes the world, then sets it back.
Thou art the fire behind my song,
The right to which I've always belonged.
I'd trade the gold of sunset skies,
The echo where the thunder dies,
For just one tear that stains thy cheek—
A sacred wound I'd kiss and keep.
No mountain high, no valley deep,
Could match the promises we keep
In silence, touch, in breath, in trust—
For nothing less than thee, I must.

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

instance_metrics.response:
"'Twas noontide of summer,' and golden the light
That poured through the leaves in a shimmering stream,
Drenching the meadows in amber and white,
As if the world dreamed in a sunlit reverie.
Bees hummed their hymns in the clovered air,
And crickets kept time with a fiddle’s refrain,
While butterflies danced without weight or care,
Drunk on nectar and summer’s warm rain.
No shadow dared challenge the blaze of the hour,
Not even the whisper of evening drew near;
The sky wore its sapphire in regal power,
And time seemed to pause, held motionless here.
A brook laughed softly, its secrets half-sung,
Reflecting the sky in a liquid blue tongue.
A child lay dreaming beneath an oak's crown,
Watching clouds drift like sails drifting down
To lands he'd imagine when daylight was done—
All beneath summer’s unblinking sun.
Oh, to live in that moment, unburdened, uncurst,
Where joy is as vast and as deep as the thirst
That noon, in its fullness, so freely imparts—
A poem of sunlight, stitched into hearts.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

instance_metrics.response:
'Twas noontide of summer,' and heat rose in waves,
A mirage of silence above the wheat fields;
Nature held breath in the cradle of days,
Where sunlight like honey the green landscape gilds.
No bird dared to sing in the thick, drowsy air,
Yet dragonflies darted on iridescent wings,
And shadows, like secrets, lay coiled in their lair
Beneath ancient oaks where the cool darkness clings.
The world stood suspended in molten delight,
Each blade of grass tipped with a flame of gold;
Even the wind took a nap in the night
Of noon’s blazing empire, too bright to be bold.
A lone scarecrow sagged in the corn’s whispered rows,
Guardian of dreams that the earth dares to grow.
Somewhere, a well sang a cool, dripping tune,
And children once raced, but now nap in the shade,
While time, like a spoon, stirs the sky into noon,
And summer declares: 'This moment was made.'
In this pause between morning and evening’s soft call,
We taste eternity—brief, blazing, and tall.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

instance_metrics.response:
'Twas noontide of summer,' when hours stood still,
And light wore the world like a luminous shawl;
The air thick with drowse, yet alive with a thrill,
As crickets and locusts composed nature’s psalm.
Fields shimmered in silence, a breath held too long,
While poppies like embers burned crimson and bold;
A crow cut the stillness with one croaking song,
Then vanished again into heat’s molten hold.
The river, a ribbon of silver and glass,
Mirrored the sky in a dreamy repose;
A heron stood statue-still, waiting to pass
The perfect moment as only time knows.
A child dipped bare toes in the water’s cool kiss,
While dragonflies skated on iridescent wings;
In that sun-soaked instant, there was nothing amiss—
Only peace, and the song that the August wind sings.
Oh, to bottle this noon, to preserve its sweet hush,
When the world, in full bloom, was too radiant to rush.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

instance_metrics.response:
'Twas noontide of summer,' the zenith of light,
When shadows retreated and hid 'neath the trees;
The sun ruled the sky with unyielding might,
And painted the earth in a blaze of unease.
Yet beauty arose from the heat’s heavy hand,
In lavender fields buzzing with drowsy delight,
In stone walls kissed green by a patient vine’s stand,
And orchards sagging with ripeness and light.
A farmer wiped sweat as he paused by the gate,
His hat pulled low, eyes squinting at skies so wide;
Even time seemed to hesitate, hesitate,
As if summer’s full heart could no longer hide.
Somewhere, a flute played a tune soft and low,
From a porch where an elder rocked, drifting and slow.
Children once splashed in the creek’s shallow pool,
Now snoozed in the shade, lulled by crickets' refrain;
While somewhere, a poet, inspired by the rule
Of light’s golden tyranny, penned joy and pain.
For noon is a prophet, both cruel and divine—
It burns, it reveals, it makes mortals feel time.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

instance_metrics.response:
'Twas noontide of summer,' and light poured like wine,
Drenching the hills in a gilded cascade;
No corner untouched by its brilliance benign,
No soul left unmarked by the sun’s grand parade.
Fields of tall rye shimmered under its gaze,
Bees wove through blossoms in drunken delight;
Even the stones seemed to hum in a daze,
Bathed in a radiance both tender and bright.
A hammock swayed gently between two old pines,
Empty, yet cradling dreams left behind;
A book lay abandoned, its spine to the skies,
As if thought itself had been struck blind.
Somewhere, a whistle—a train far away—
Cut through the silence, then melted like clay.
A dog dreamed of chasing in paws that would twitch,
While roses, too bold, spilled their scent on the air;
And children, half-conscious, still whispered a wish
To live in this glow, free from labor or care.
Oh, to stay here, where the world is aglow,
Where time moves in honey, and soft breezes blow.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

instance_metrics.response:
'Twas noontide of summer,' when light reigned supreme,
And shadows were scarce, mere whispers below;
Each leaf, every stone, caught a golden-gleam,
As if the world wore a luminous glow.
No wind stirred the grass, yet the air hummed with song—
Not sung by birds, but by heat’s quiet thrum;
A language of stillness, where all belonged
To the hush that the sun had ordained to become.
A pond, mirror-calm, held the sky upside-down,
Where clouds like slow ships sailed through liquid blue;
A frog leapt, then stilled, without splash or frown,
As if even motion were subject to noon’s decree.
A scarecrow stood guard in a field of tall corn,
Its burlap face baked by hours so warm;
While somewhere, a child, weary, born
Of play and of sun, dreamed of shade and of storm.
Yet storms were far off, and shade but a thought;
This moment was heaven—too perfect, too fraught.

'Twas noontide of summer,' and light poured like fire,
Not burning, but blessing each stem and each stone;
The world held its breath in a moment of pyre,

To thirsty roots hidden beneath garden gate.
No clock dared to chime in that ageless expanse,

'Twas noontide of summer,' when light ruled the land,
And shadows like thieves hid beneath every tree;

A tractor sat idle in fields of ripe wheat,

While roses, too bold, spilled their perfume so sweet,

A kite, once aloft, now lay tangled in twine,

A porch swing creaked softly, in rhythm and rhyme,

Then silence returned, and the world fell asleep.

For noon is a priest in a temple of gold,

Not the kind in stained glass or scripture,

instance_metrics.response: For the first time in my life, I ate a peach and didn’t rush. Juice ran down my wrist, sticky and sweet, and I let it. No napkin. No wiping. Just indulgence in the mess of delight. The flesh was golden, fragrant, bursting with summer’s last breath. I closed my eyes and tasted not just fruit, but memory—of orchards, of childhood, of hands that planted this tree. Each bite was a small rebellion against efficiency, against cleanliness, against the myth of control. I sucked the pit clean, not with shame, but with joy. This was not gluttony. This was gratitude. For the first time in my life, pleasure wasn’t earned. It was claimed. I licked my fingers, savoring the residue, the evidence of enjoyment. A bee circled, drawn to the sweetness I left behind. I didn’t shoo it. We shared the moment, the sun, the spoils. And when only the pit remained, I held it like a trophy. Not of consumption, but of presence. I had been here. I had tasted. I had loved. instance_metrics.response: For the first time in my life, I sat with grief and didn’t try to fix it. It sat beside me on the couch, heavy, familiar, wearing my father’s old sweater. It had been exiled for years, called 'unproductive,' 'unbecoming.' But today, it was welcome. We watched rain slide down the window, each drop a memory. I didn’t cry. I didn’t speak. I just existed with it, like an old friend who’d traveled far. And slowly, grief softened—not gone, but seen. For the first time in my life, I understood: healing isn’t about erasure. It’s about inclusion. The ache wasn’t a flaw. It was love with nowhere to go. I touched the empty cup, still warm, and whispered, 'Thank you.' Not for the pain, but for the proof. instance_metrics.response:
In the forest where trees remembered everything,
where roots spoke in slow, deep tones,
their flags and their banners they are waving with joy
and excitement they shout—not with mouths,
but with color, with scent, with light.

The banners are made of moss, of lichen, of peeling bark,
of flowers that open only at dawn.

They wave them in the wind’s slow breath,
above ferns that uncurl like fists.

A deer raises its head, antlers draped with vines—
its crown a standard of wild grace.

They shout not in words, but in rustles,
in birdcalls, in the crack of a falling branch.

"The rain came!"
"The fawn stands!"
"The mycelium sings tonight!"

This is the Gathering of the Green,
where every leaf is a flag,
every root a shout of continuity.

And when the moon rises, silver and still,
the forest pulses with quiet jubilation,
its banners fluttering in bioluminescent hues.

For joy, in the wild,
needs no name.
It only needs soil,
and time,
and the courage to grow,
to wave,
to be—
unseen, perhaps, but deeply, fiercely alive.

Each wave a memory, each a tear,
Each crest a knock upon the door.

I fear the fall from steady ground,
The lie that wears a lover’s face,
The echo of a missing sound,
The slow retreat of time and grace.

They wear the shape of empty rooms,
Of letters never sent or read,
Of flowers wilted in their blooms,
Of words I wish I’d left unsaid.

They gather strength in quiet hours,
When clocks tick loud and thoughts run deep,
When loneliness becomes a power,
And shadows make the promises we keep.

But then—a child begins to laugh,
A kettle sings, a door swings wide,
And for a breath, the fears grow half,
And courage stirs, though still denied.

For fear may stretch from dusk to dawn,
But so does wonder, fierce and near.
And though the dark still presses on,
I find that light persists right here.

My God, how many are my fears!
Perhaps as many as the waves.
But You still hold me through the years,
And even fear can’t break these caves.

My God, how many are my fears!
They crawl like ants beneath my skin,
Each one a doubt from vanished years,
A war I lost before I’d win.

I fear the knock, the phone, the text,
The silence after ‘I love you,’
The final breath, the funeral text,
The sky that turns to endless blue.

They live in closets, under beds,
In attic trunks of childhood pain,
In dreams where I am left for dead,
And wake to find it all the same.

They tell me I am not enough,
That love will fade, that trust will break,
That every road will lead to rough,
And every dawn will end in ache.

But then—a poem, soft and low,
A touch, a tune, a sudden grace,
And for a breath, the fears let go,
And I remember my own face.

My God, how many are my fears!
Too many to name, too deep to hold.
But You are near through all the years,
And even dread can’t freeze my soul.

For though they swarm like winter’s breath,
There’s warmth beneath, a hidden flame,
A truth that conquers fear with death:
I’m not alone. I bear Your name.

They bloom like weeds in fertile doubt,
Their roots entwined in childhood years,

One fears the knock at dead of night,

They wear the masks of what-ifs, spun

Each one a whisper: Never the same.

Convince my heart the final test
Is one from which I’ll rise up dead.

But in the stillness, past the noise,
A different voice begins to rise—
Not bold, not brave, but full of poise:
‘You’re scared, and still, you open eyes.’

My God, how many are my fears!
Too vast to number, deep to bear.
But here I stand, still drawing breath,
And facing dark with fainting prayer.

And every time you start anew,
It mends the cracks and makes you whole.’

My God, how many are my fears!
Too many to defeat or name.
But You still whisper through the years:
‘My child, I know them all the same.’

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Not empty, but deep with reprise.
They hold the weight of swallowed screams,
And fractured suns in midnight dreams.
His brow is furrowed with ancient lore,
Of kingdoms lost and wars no more.
He speaks in riddles wrapped in sighs,
Beneath the veil of cloudless skies.
They say he’s cursed, that he’s unwell,
But I hear bells in his rebel yell.
His madness isn’t loss of mind,
But vision the sane left behind.
He sees the roots beneath the rose,
The sorrow each laughter owes.
And in his gaze, I start to know
The fragile line we all forgo.
So I kneel down, not in defeat,
But in awe at truths so bittersweet.
He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—
And finally, I realize.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

instance_metrics.response:
He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Not wild, but wise in strange disguise.
They glint like shards of shattered glass,
Reflecting futures that never pass.
I freeze, not from fright, but from grace,
As time slows in that haunted place.
His breath is a hymn from another age,
Whispering through a scholar’s cage.
He’s read the book the world forgot,
Where answers come at a heavy cost.
They chain him, call him lost, insane,
But sanity’s just a social chain.
And in his pupils, I glimpse the core—
The truth we bury, beg, ignore.
That love is fire, and life is brief,
That joy is pain in different leaf.
So I hold his stare, unafraid,
For in his madness, I’m remade.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

instance_metrics.response:
He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And suddenly, all my truths disguise.
They burn with colors no name can hold,
Stories of silver, myths of gold.
His irises swirl like storm-fed seas,
Carrying lost philosophies.
I hear the rustle of unseen wings,
As reality softly sings
A tune it only reveals at night,
When logic dissolves in pale moonlight.
He’s not broken—he’s overfull,
A mind that broke its mortal skull.
He sees the cracks in every lie,
The tears behind every "I’m fine."
And though they lock him in cold white rooms,
His spirit blooms in silent gloom.
I touch his hand, and for a breath,
I see beyond the veil of death.
He looks at me with a madman’s stare—
And I know: he’s been everywhere.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

instance_metrics.response:
He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And I see eternity’s disguise.
Not madness, but a lens too clear,
That magnifies what we hold dear.
He sees the pulse beneath the skin,
The lies we wear to let us in.
His breath is syncopated, slow,
As if he knows what none dare know.
They say he’s lost, that he’s unwhole,
But I see the making of a soul.
A mind that touched the edge of things,
Where silence flaps on raven wings.
He mouths a word I can’t define—
A name for God, or the end of time.
And in that gaze, I start to fall
Through layers of the great, deep wall
That separates us from the real.
He looks at me—and I can feel
The universe breathe. And then, he winks.
The madman knows. And I… I think.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

instance_metrics.response:
He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And in them, all my masks demise.
They flicker with unspoken fire,

Not chaos, but a different order,
A truth too sharp for any border.
He sees the child I used to be,

They call him broken, lost, unkind,

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

instance_metrics.response:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy that dances in the morning light,
For dew-kissed grass and sparrows' songs that pierce the hush of night.
For children’s laughter, wild and clear, like wind chimes in the breeze,
And fireflies that flicker hope beneath the ancient trees.

Blessed be Thou for quiet hands that knead the bread with care,
For stories whispered round the fire, for burdens we can bear.
For every tear that turns to grace, for wounds that slowly mend,
For love that lingers through the years, a faithful, steadfast friend.

Blessed be Thou for thunderous skies and oceans vast and wide,
For stars that scribble ancient truths across the endless tide.
For art that aches with holy longing, for music that can heal,
For wounds that teach us how to kneel, yet make us strong to feel.

Blessed be Thou for seasons turning, for endings that begin,
For every breath, a whispered hymn that draws the soul within.
Not only for the sunlit paths, but shadows where we grow,
For in the dark, Your presence glows — and this, too, we bestow.

Blessed be Thou, O Source of all, from whom all blessings flow.
In joy and grief, in rise and fall, Your love remains — and so.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

instance_metrics.response:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy that hums beneath the skin of things —
the kettle’s song, the cat’s soft purr, the way the quiet sings.
For dappled light through summer leaves that paint the forest floor,
and moments when the world stands still, and time unlocks the door.

For coffee steam that curls like psalms, for books with dog-eared pages,
For strangers’ smiles on crowded streets, for wisdom in old ages.
For gardens where the marigolds defy the stubborn clay,
And hope, a stubborn, sunlit weed, returns to greet the day.

Blessed be Thou for friendships forged in laughter, loss, and wine,
For hands that hold when strength is gone, for knowing you are mine.
For songs remembered, half-unsung, that rise when hearts are sore,
For dreams reborn behind closed eyes, for keys that open more.

Blessed be Thou for all that breaks and still finds ways to bloom,
For grief that carves a deeper space for joy to fill the room.
For every 'no' that led to 'yes,' for paths we didn’t choose,
For quiet grace that walks with us, and pain that love can use.

Blessed be Thou — not just for peaks, but valleys where You stay.
In every breath, in night and dawn, You shape us, come what may.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

instance_metrics.response:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy that shimmers in the small —
the dandelion cracking stone, the robin’s springtime call.
For crumbs of kindness, freely shared, for bread broken in two,
For eyes that meet across a room and know exactly you.

Blessed be Thou for thunderstorms that shake the windowpane,
For rain that drums a lullaby and washes roads with rain.
For thunder’s voice, a primal hymn, for lightning’s silver thread,
And silence after chaos, where Your whisper can be read.

Blessed be Thou for art that dares to wound and then to heal,
For poems etched in midnight hours when sorrow makes us real.
For dancers leaping toward the sky, for painters lost in hue,
For every soul who turns their pain to something bright and true.

Blessed be Thou for aging hands, for lines that map a life,
For children’s questions, deep and strange, that cut through fear and strife.
For coffee shared in quiet dawn, for blankets warm and deep,
For promises we barely keep, yet still, You let us sleep.

Blessed be Thou for all that lives, for death that births the new,
For every end that is a start — because, O God, we’re through.
Through sorrow, through the silent nights, through battles none can see,
Your joy remains — not loud, but low, a constant, steady plea.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

instance_metrics.response:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy that flickers in the mundane —
a sock unmatched, a tune half-sung, a sunbeam on the lane.
For toast that burns, for dogs that snore, for laughter at the spill,
For awkward hugs and clumsy words that somehow love fulfill.

Blessed be Thou for subway songs and market vendors’ cries,
For children building cardboard forts beneath indifferent skies.
For graffiti blooming on the walls, for rebels with a cause,
For quiet courage in the dark, for breaking unjust laws.

Blessed be Thou for every 'no' that guarded sacred ground,
For boundaries drawn with gentle hands, for healing to be found.
For therapists who listen deep, for tears that fall like rain,
For learning how to say, 'I need,' and not dissolve in shame.

Blessed be Thou for aging parents, frail but still so wise,
For stories told a hundred times beneath familiar skies.
For memories that shimmer gold, for legacies that last,
For knowing you were loved, and that the love was meant to last.

Blessed be Thou for breath that wakes, for dreams that dare to soar,
For every crack where light breaks in, and still You love us more.

instance_metrics.response:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy that rises from the ache —
the mother’s sigh, the newborn’s cry, the world that starts to wake.

Blessed be Thou for libraries where silence sings with thought,

For questions asked without an end, for wonder in the why,
For stars that mock our tiny lives beneath a vaulted sky.

Blessed be Thou for lovers’ hands that brush in passing near,
For glances held a second long, for love that conquers fear.
For weddings simple, humble, true, for vows that stretch through years,
For learning how to stay, and how to dry another’s tears.

Blessed be Thou for forests deep where no one else has trod,
For mushrooms sprouting in the dark, for paths that lead to God.
For moss that carpets ancient stone, for roots that grip and climb,
For nature’s quiet liturgy, untouched by space or time.

Blessed be Thou for every breath, for life that will not cease,
For joy that wears a thousand masks — and all of them, Your peace.

instance_metrics.response:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy that hides in broken things —
a teacup glued with golden seams, the song a sparrow sings
from telephone wires in the slum, where children leap and play,
where hope survives on scraps of time and music made from clay.

Blessed be Thou for refugee tales told softly in the night,
for courage wrapped in tattered coats, for battles won in flight.
For mothers shielding sleeping heads with arms both bruised and strong,
For lullabies in languages that don’t belong to long.

Blessed be Thou for workers bent beneath the midday sun,
for hands that build, for hands that heal, for every job undone.
For teachers shaping futures blind, for farmers sowing seeds,
For bakers sending morning scent on merciful, soft breezes.

Blessed be Thou for silence after bombs, for peace that dares to grow,
For olive trees replanted where the shrapnel used to go.
For enemies who share a meal, for truth that breaks the chain,
For joy that blooms in no-man’s-land, despite the wind and rain.

Blessed be Thou for every soul who dares to still believe,
For joy that is not happiness, but how we still receive.

the mycelium beneath the soil, the rhythm in our brains.

instance_metrics.response:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy that sparkles in the mess —
the crayon on the kitchen wall, the dog’s enthusiastic kiss.
For toys abandoned in the hall, for socks beneath the bed,
For chaos shaped by tiny hands, where love is freely fed.

Blessed be Thou for bedtime tales with voices soft and low,
For monsters banished by a hug, for watching eyelids slow.
For 'just one more' that turns to three, for songs we sing off-key,
For lullabies that wrap the night like You’re right here with me.

Blessed be Thou for scraped-up knees and tears that soak my shirt,
For 'Daddy, hold me, please' — the sweetest words that ever hurt.
For bandaids shaped like butterflies, for kisses on the air,
For knowing I’m the fortress here, though I’m barely aware.

Blessed be Thou for growing pains, for questions big and small,
For 'Why is grass green, God?' and 'Will You catch me if I fall?'
For teaching faith with popsicle sticks, for prayers before mac ‘n’ cheese,
For joy that builds a childhood up — one moment at a breeze.

Blessed be Thou for all the days that blur into a stream,
For being loved, for being dad — the greatest joy, it seems.

Blessed be Thou for desert nights where stars feel close enough to touch,

Blessed be Thou for sacred spaces, hidden, hushed, and deep,

the blues that bend the soul awake, the wind through autumn trees.

Blessed be Thou for novels thick with lives we’ve never known,

For endings bittersweet and true, for love that isn’t clean,

Blessed be Thou for comedy that laughs at pain and pride,

Blessed be Thou for firelight that paints the ceiling gold,

Blessed be Thou for northern lights that ripple through the sky,

For awe that steals the breath away, for wonder without name,
For joy that doesn’t need a reason — just a heart that dares to flame.

Blessed be Thou for evergreens that brave the blizzard’s scorn,
For roots that grip the frozen earth, for hope reborn each morn.
For children sledding down the hill, for laughter sharp as glass,
For joy that thrives when everything seems bent on making mass.

Blessed be Thou for seasons locked in ice, yet pulsing with the spring,
For joy that doesn’t fear the dark, but learns to spread its wing.

the glance that needs no explanation, the songbird never heard.

For joy that walks on velvet feet and never makes a sound.

Blessed be Thou for animals that trust without a test,
For cats that curl upon our chests, for dogs that guard our rest.
For horses that can read a heart, for birds that build with care,
For creatures living in the now, without a single prayer.

Blessed be Thou for oceans deep where light begins to fade,
For creatures glowing in the black, for choices never made.
For coral reefs in silent bloom, for tides that ebb and flow,
For joy that doesn’t know its name, yet sings the world below.

Blessed be Thou for forests where the ferns uncurl in shade,
For mushrooms feeding on the dead, for cycles unafraid.
For death that feeds the living soil, for life that won’t stay still,
For joy that isn’t human-shaped, yet hums beneath the hill.

Blessed be Thou for every pulse, for every breath, for all that stirs,
For joy that doesn’t need a soul — just being is enough, it earns.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

instance_metrics.response:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy that lives inside the fight —
the activist with weary eyes, the soldier in the night.
For whistleblowers who speak the truth and pay the heavy cost,
For joy that stands when others run, and counts the lives it’s lost.

Blessed be Thou for courage drawn from sources deep and dim,
For widows marching through the streets, for songs that rise from him.
For joy that wears a bulletproof vest, for prayers beneath the gun,
For mothers shouting names to sky where justice has not come.

Blessed be Thou for every hand that builds a barricade
not out of hate, but love so fierce it dares to disobey.
For joy that kneels in protest, for breath that chants 'We are!'
For hope that beats in prison cells where silence is the law.

Blessed be Thou for journalists who risk to tell the tale,
For doctors in the warzone, for the ones who will not fail.
For teachers in the bombed-out schools, for joy that writes a rhyme,
For children learning 'peace' in lands that know not how or time.

Blessed be Thou for joy that will not bow, that will not cease,
For joy that is the anthem of a world that longs for peace.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

instance_metrics.response:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy that hides in waiting rooms,
for IVs dripping hope, for flowers in the gloom.
For nurses with a joke to ease the fear, for doctors who just *see*,
For joy that walks the hospital halls, where life and death agree.

Blessed be Thou for newborn cries that split the sterile air,
For hands that tremble holding life beyond all thought or prayer.
For joy that blooms in incubators, fragile, thin, and new,
For every breath a miracle, a gift, a 'thank you'.

Blessed be Thou for elders fading, memories grown thin,
For joy that lives in 'I love yous' when all the rest wears thin.
For songs from distant decades, hummed in voices soft and low,
For joy that doesn’t need a mind to know the love still grows.

Blessed be Thou for surgeries that mend the broken bone,
For scans that show the tumor shrunk, for being left alone.
For joy that isn’t cure, but presence in the pain,
For knowing You are with us, whispering our name.

Blessed be Thou for healing slow, for strength that must be earned,
For joy that is not freedom, but the will to still return.

Blessed be Thou for every flaw, for every scar, for all that’s torn,

instance_metrics.response: Blessed be Thou for all the joy that dances in the morning light, for golden rays that gild the dew-kissed fields and send the larks in spirals bright. Blessed be Thou for hands that hold when sorrow bends the weary spine, for bread that breaks, for stories told beneath a canopy of stars that shine. For every spark that leaps unseen—a glance, a dream, a sudden grace—Thou art the pulse behind the scene, the rhythm in each fleeting face. Blessed be Thou when silence speaks in cathedral hush of falling snow, when joy is not in peaks or peaks, but in the warmth we come to know. For every tear that turns to praise, for every wound that learns to heal, for nights that teach the gift of days, for every wound that time can seal. Blessed be Thou, not just for wings, but for the roots that keep us near, for joy that wears humility’s guise, and draws us ever closer, dear. In every breath, in every sigh, in every dawn that dares renew—Blessed be Thou, O endless sky, for making all things beautiful.

instance_metrics.response:
Lonely is the moon, adrift in velvet night,
A silver sentinel with no stars in sight.
It casts its pallid glow on sleeping shores,
While silence deepens behind closed doors.
No echo answers when it dares to sigh,
Just shadows folding as time drifts by.
It watches oceans rise with borrowed light,
Yet feels no warmth, no touch, no right
To claim a kinship with the worlds below—
A lonely god with nowhere to go.
It sees lovers entwined in passionate flame,
Hears children whisper each other’s name,
But orbits on, a ghostly sphere,
Haunted by love it cannot hear.
Its craters hold the ache of centuries,
Filled with unshed tears and memories
Of suns it once danced near, now long since gone,
Leaving only the void to carry on.
Lonely is not the absence of sound,
But the presence of need without being found.
It’s the breath before a word is spoken,
The thread that frays but won’t be broken.
Lonely is the moon, and so am I—
Hanging in darkness, learning to cry
Without making a sound, without anyone near,
Just gravity’s pull and the weight of a tear.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'lonely'

instance_metrics.response:
A single bench beneath a barren tree,
Where autumn winds hum lullabies to me.
I trace the cracks in weathered wood and stone,
Each groove a story I’ve faced, and faced alone.
The park is hushed—no laughter, no feet,
Just pigeons pecking at old bread and heat
That isn’t there. The sky wears gray,
A mirror to the thoughts I cannot say.
Lonely isn’t always being apart,
But feeling invisible inside a crowd’s heart.
It’s smiling when asked, “Are you okay?”
While storms ignite behind your eyes all day.
It’s scrolling through a thousand blinking lights,
Searching for a soul who feels as I,
But finding only echoes dressed as friends,
Messages that begin but never mend.
Lonely is the space between breaths,
The pause where hope quietly steps
Back, afraid to stir the dust of dreams
That settled thick on forgotten seams.
It’s the coffee grown cold beside an open book,
The second glass of wine with nothing to cook.
It’s knowing names, but never being known,
Building a world in a house of bone.
Yet in this hush, a whisper starts to grow—
A quiet strength only the lonely know.
For in the stillness, truth begins to bloom,
And even shadows can outlast the gloom.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'lonely'

instance_metrics.response:
Lonely is a train at 2 a.m.,
Steel rails singing a hymn without hymn.
Fog presses close against the glass,
Reflecting faces that never pass.
Each seat a confession booth unoccupied,
Each light outside a life I haven’t tried.
My breath fogs words I cannot speak—
Promises whispered, now growing weak.
A suitcase rests by my quiet feet,
Filled with memories I can’t delete.
It rattles in rhythm with every turn,
Like bones remembering where they’ve burned.
Lonely is the hum beneath the wheels,
The sound of distance no kiss can heal.
It’s knowing cities flash beyond my view,
Full of embraces I’ve never knew.
A baby cries in the next car down,
A mother’s hush a soft, sad crown.
I envy them—not for love they share,
But for the knowing that someone’s there.
Lonely isn’t empty space or time,
But carrying a soul that won’t align
With any other—out of phase and slow,
Like a melody no one else can know.
Yet in this motion, with no home in sight,
There blooms a strange, unasked-for light.
For in the solitude of night’s long run,
I meet the self I’ve always outrun.
And though no hand reaches across the seat,
I find, within, a presence sweet—
Not loud, not warm, but deep and true:
The only company I’ve ever knew.

instance_metrics.response:
In the attic corner, dust drapes thick,
Over a music box with a frozen trick.
Its ballerina poised on one toe,
Waiting for fingers that no one will show.
Wind it up? But who would hear the tune?
A waltz for shadows beneath a dull moon.
Lonely isn’t silence—it’s sound unheard,
Like a symphony played for a vacant world.
It’s the phone that never rings, though I wait,
The name that fades from a birthday slate.
It’s handwriting on letters unsent,
Sealed with tears and deep lament.
I walk through rooms where laughter once bounced,
Now every echo feels self-announced.
Footsteps too loud on hollow floors,
Knocking on doors behind closed doors.
Lonely is the garden gone to seed,
Where roses strangle in choking weed.
I planted love with careful hands,
But no one came to tend the lands.
Now thorns wear crowns where petals curled,
And dreams lie buried in this quiet world.
Yet in the dust, a thought takes wing—
Perhaps to be lonely means I still can sing.
For even if no ear attends the strain,
The heart still pulses, again, again.
And in that pulse, a truth is born:
To feel the ache means I am not quite gone.
So let the music box stay still and cold—
Its silence speaks a story bold.
And I, like it, though no one sees,
Am more than just what loneliness breeds.

instance_metrics.response:
The lighthouse stands on a cliff of stone,
Its beam slicing night, utterly alone.
No ship answers its urgent call,
Just waves that crash and never recall.
Lonely is the light that guides the way
For others’ journeys, but has none to stay.
It spins and spins through storm and calm,
A steady heart beneath a weeping palm.
Its windows watch the endless sea,
A mirror of its own debris—
Shattered hopes like shells below,
And tides that come and never know.
It knows the shape of every star,
Yet cannot touch them from afar.
It sees the coast, but feels no sand,
Trapped in duty, not demand.
Lonely isn’t chosen, nor is it not—
It simply is, like a forgotten thought.
It’s the keeper who climbs the spiral stair,
Whistling to ghosts in the salty air.
He speaks to seabirds, names them all,

His logbook fills with weather and time,
And entries fade like a dying chime.
Yet every night, the light still burns,
Though no one sees, and no one returns.
For in its loneliness, a purpose grows—
A quiet grace that no one knows.
To shine without reward, to guard without praise,
Is to love the world in silent ways.
And so the lighthouse, though apart,
Holds the ocean close to heart.
In its solitude, a truth takes flight:
Loneliness can be a kind of light.

An old record spins in a vacant room,
Billie’s voice filling the gathering gloom.
Her blues curl like smoke through the air,
Singing of love that wasn’t fair.
I don’t dance, but my heart keeps time
To rhythms lost in another’s rhyme.
Lonely is this vinyl’s worn refrain,
Playing for no one, again, again.
It’s the needle’s skip, the crackle and hiss,
A broken record of what I miss.
Not just a person, not just a face,
But the warmth of touch, the shared embrace
Of ordinary moments—soup on the stove,
Quiet talk over morning love.
Now silence follows every sound,
And emptiness wears my clothes around.
Lonely is the mirror’s cold reply,
Reflecting a question in a weary eye:
Who am I when no one sees?
Just echoes rustling through empty trees.
Yet in the music, something stirs—
A pulse beneath the loneliness, a verse
That says, I am here, I feel, I ache,
And that, in darkness, is no small stake.
For even sorrow, when truly known,
Becomes a seed in barren stone.
And as the record nears its end,
I find I can listen, and still befriend
The quiet, the hush, the space, the ache—
For in my loneliness, I am awake.

instance_metrics.response:
A single sock drifts in the washing drum,
Spinning and lost, with no partner come.
Where is the one that completes its pair?
Lost in the folds of thin air.
Lonely is this orphaned thread,
Searching for warmth it thought it had.
It clings to scents of skin and soap,
Memories of a tighter scope.
It once knew pressure, pressure of toes,
The brush of fabric where comfort grows.
Now it flaps in mechanical rain,
A dance without rhythm, without gain.
Lonely isn’t always vast or deep—
It’s small losses that make us weep.
A key with no lock, a shoe with no mate,
A plate set for one at the garden gate.
It’s the second glove left in the snow,
The name forgotten, the voice too low.
It’s the last cookie, the final pill,
The quiet ache no one will still.
Yet in its spinning, the sock finds grace—
It learns to whirl in empty space.
It becomes something beyond its plan:
A flag of one, a rebel strand.
And though it may never find its twin,
It dances on, letting the cycle spin.
For in its solitude, it starts to sing:
‘I am not broken. I am a thing
That exists, that moves, that knows the spin—
And in being alone, I am not quite in.
But here. Present. Still part of the run.
Even a single sock is someone.’

instance_metrics.response:
The last leaf clings to the winter oak,
Brittle and brown, a whispered croak
Of color in a monochrome sky.
It trembles, but refuses to die.
Lonely is this final hold,
This defiance against the cold.
All others fell with autumn’s grace,
Now it stares into endless space.
No breeze speaks gently; they howl instead,
Tearing through branches, stripping the dead.
Yet still it grips with a withered stem,
A tiny fist cursing the stem.
Lonely isn’t giving up the fight,
But standing witness to endless night.
It sees the squirrels have long since fled,
The birds migrated, the sky turned red
With sunset’s brief, indifferent flame,

It hears the creak of ancient wood,
A language only the solitary could.
Lonely is the song it cannot sing,

But silence, frost, and time’s slow creep—
Yet in its stillness, it learns to keep
A kind of peace no crowd affords:
The truth of being, without rewards.
And when at last the wind wins through,
It falls—not broken, but finally true.
For it fell as one, not lost, but known—
The last leaf who faced the storm alone.

instance_metrics.response:
A notebook lies open on a wooden desk,
Ink still wet, but no hand to press
The next word forward. The room is still,
Frozen in thought, against its will.
Lonely is the sentence left undone,
A bridge of meaning never begun.
It hovers like a bird mid-flight,
Afraid of landing, afraid of night.
The pen rolls slightly, as if to say,
‘Write me the truth, don’t look away.’
But truth is heavy when spoken alone,
A weight the heart was never known
to carry without a witness near,
A pair of eyes to hold the tear.
Lonely is the draft, the crossed-out line,
The poem hidden, the unshared sign.
It’s the journal filled with coded pain,
And dreams erased by morning’s rain.
It’s the email typed but never sent,
The love confessed in a basement vent.
Yet in this quiet, letters form,
Not for an audience, but the storm
Inside the chest, the silent war
That makes the poet, makes the core.
And so the page, though blank in part,
Still holds the beating of a heart.
For writing to oneself is not defeat—
It’s conversation, raw and sweet.
And in the silence, word by word,
The lonely writer is finally heard.

A streetlamp flickers in the suburban lane,

Lonely is this steady, blinking eye,
Watching houses where people lie

It sees curtains drawn, lights turned low,

It casts long shadows that twist and lean,

Lonely isn’t absence of light,
But shining without being seen right.

From dusk till dawn, without pause or praise,

It hears the crickets, the distant train,

But no one speaks to it, not even once,

Not for applause, but because it’s a glob

For even if unloved, unseen, unknown,

The desert stretches, vast and bare,

Lonely is this spined prophet,
Guarding secrets the sands won’t let
Escape the wind. No bloom appears,

It drinks the sun, it breathes the heat,
And roots down deep where life’s discreet.
Lonely isn’t barrenness or lack—
It’s growing slow on a barren track,
Where every inch is hard-won ground,

It hears the scuttle of a lone gecko,

But no embrace, no vine to twine,
Just thorns that mark a boundary line.
Lonely is the bloom that never comes,

The soil awake. And yet, one night,

Of rain, it flowers—white and brief—
A burst of joy, a moment’s grief.
No bee to carry its sweet decree,
Just moonlight on its purity.
But it bloomed. It dared. It showed its face
To an empty sky, with quiet grace.
For loneliness, in its deepest form,
Is not the absence, but the norm
Of being seen by no one’s eye,
And still choosing to try.
And in that bloom, though brief, though lone,
The desert whispers: You’re not unknown.

A chessboard set at the window’s edge,
One player gone, one still pledges
To move the white king through the night.
Black sits in wait—cold, out of sight.
Lonely is the game with no mind
To match your own, to be entwined
In thought and counter, feint and play.
Just silent pieces in disarray.
Each move is answered by empty air,
A check that finds no one there.
The queen lies fallen, the bishop pinned,
Memories of wars that might have been.
Lonely isn’t losing the fight,
But winning alone in the pale lamplight.
It’s the strategy perfected in vain,
The brilliant trap with no one to chain.
It’s setting up the pieces each day,

Yet in the stillness, a truth emerges—
This game, though solitary, surges
With quiet pride. Each move a thought,
Each loss a lesson dearly bought.
And though no hand reaches across the square,
The mind still dances in the air.
For chess, like life, is often played
In silence, where dreams are made
Not from wins, but from the try,
From standing tall beneath an empty sky.
And so the player moves the knight,
Not for glory, but for light—
The inner glow of moves well made,
Of being present, unafraid.
Lonely? Yes. But not undone.
The game goes on. The king moves on.

An astronaut floats in the capsule’s glow,
Earth a blue jewel, soft and slow
Below the glass. No sound, no breath,
Just the hum of machines after death
Of conversation. Mission Control
Has signed off. He’s lost the role
Of hero now, just man in suit,
Adrift in silence, absolute.
Lonely is this cosmic drift,
Where stars don’t twinkle, just persist
In cold, unblinking, distant rows.
No wind, no touch, no one to propose
A toast, no hand to hold his own,
Just weightless bones and microwaved bone.
He watches continents slide by,
Families sleeping beneath the sky.
He thinks of kids, of bedtime tales,
Of warm milk and unbroken nails.
Lonely isn’t space or height,
But proximity without the light
Of contact. He’s close—yet galaxies
Away in soul and memories.
Yet in this void, a wonder grows—
A peace that only silence knows.
For in the absence of every sound,
The universe whispers all around:
‘You are small. You are alone.
But you are part of this vast unknown.’
And in that truth, both sharp and deep,
The astronaut finds a quiet sleep—
Not of the body, but of the core,
A oneness with the endless door.
And though no voice breaks through the night,
He feels, at last, a kind of light.

Of every sorrow, every cry,
That once soared beneath a sky
Of listening hearts, of tear-streaked eyes,
Of shared breath beneath theater skies.
And so it waits, not dead, but paused,
A soul in wood, because it was
Chosen once, loved, set apart—
Even in silence, it holds the art.
For loneliness, when touched by grace,
Becomes a vessel, a resting place
For beauty yet to be released—
Not gone, just waiting, undiminished, peace.

And in that wait, a strength is bred—
The quiet courage of the unread.
For even if no hand should choose,
Their truths remain, and cannot lose.

An old radio crackles in the hall,
Tuned to a station that faded long ago.
Static hums like a distant psalm,
A ghost of voices that no one will know.
Lonely is this electric breath,
Seeking a signal beyond the death
Of airwaves, of songs once bright,
Now lost in the void of endless night.
It spins the dial with silent hands,
Hoping for music, for distant lands,
For a laugh, a tune, a human sound—
Anything to prove it’s not unbound
From the world of warmth, of skin, of speech.

Of jazz and ballads, long since gone,

Of connection, even if denied.

A teacup sits on a windowsill,

The shape of lips, the ghost of sips,

Lonely is this porcelain shell,
This vessel where no words could dwell.
It waited for a morning chat,
For laughter shared, for this and that.
Now silence pools within its rim,
A lake of what might have been.
Lonely isn’t cold tea or stain,
But the chair across, forever plain,
Uncreaked, unwarped by sitting bone,

A pair of boots by the back door stand,

Lonely is this footwear pair,

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the wind combs through pale grass with restless grace,
A homestead crouches, weathered and unblest,
Beneath a sky of vast, unyielding space.

In slow, unmeasured drops like desert rain.
Here, a man once dreamed of orchards, rows of wheat,
Of children’s laughter ringing through the eaves.
Now only scuttling lizards know his beat,
And rusting wire holds the memory of sheaves.
The stars at night are sharp as broken glass,
Cold witnesses to solitude’s long reign.
A kerosene lamp flickers, shadows pass—
A ghost of hope, a whisper of the plain.
No postman comes, no neighbor’s dog will bark,
Just wind, and dust, and dreams gone stark and dark.

O God! Thou art my God alone, the dawn that breaks my night,
The only truth I’ve ever known, the wellspring of my light.
I’ve bowed to idols made of clay, to dreams that turned to dust,
But only You can take the gray and fill my heart with trust.

You are the fire in winter’s breath, the song in silent pain,
The one who conquers fear with death, and life from loss regains.
You are the hand that holds the thread through every tangled zone,
And every step I take ahead is Yours and Yours alone.

No lover’s kiss, no brother’s bond, no mother’s tender tone,
Can match the love that, fierce and fond, has claimed me as Your own.
I am no longer mine to own, my will, my flesh, my bone—
I am Your vessel, fully known: O God! Thou art my God alone.

When stars grow dim and silence reigns and all my songs are flown,
My soul will rise and claim Your name: Thou art my God alone.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
In dawn's first light, I seek Thy throne.
Through shadowed vale and desert wide,
Thy presence is my constant guide.

The psalmist’s cry in ancient time,
Now echoes in this pulse and rhyme.
My soul, like parched and waiting soil,
Longs for the rain of Thy sweet toil.

Not bread nor wine, nor golden hoard,
Can fill the silence of this chord.
But just one glimpse of Thy clear face,
Awakens in me endless grace.

I’ve wandered paths where idols gleam,
False stars that flicker, false dreams.
Yet here, in silence, stripped and bare,
I find Thee—breath, and light, and air.

O let my heart be fully Thine,
No rival claim, no fractured line.
For in Thy gaze, the cosmos sings,
And I am home on broken wings.

So through the night, I watch and pray,
Until the breaking of the day.
O God! Thou art my God alone,
And in Thy love, I am fully known.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other name I breathe, no throne
But Yours, where silence speaks so loud,
A symphony within the cloud.

I trace Your steps in fallen leaves,
In tides that rise and tides that grieve.
Each breath a hymn, each tear a psalm,
The world Your psalter, calm and calm.

The stars, like dust, proclaim Your name,
Yet still, I whisper it the same—
Not in the shout, but in the hush,
Where broken hearts begin to blush.

My love, once scattered, now draws near,
A compass spinning, then held clear.
You are the North I never knew,
The depth beneath the shallow blue.

I’ve loved illusions, bright and loud,
But You—you are the hidden cloud
That rains on wastelands, makes them bloom,
Transforms the exile to the room
Where love sits waiting, warm and wide—
O God! Thou art my God, my guide,
My morning song, my midnight plea,
The only truth that sets me free.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
This truth has carved my flesh and bone.
Not in the temple, high and grand,
But in the dust, I clasp Your hand.

The world has offered gilded lies—
Ambition’s mask, desire’s disguise.
But in the stillness, stripped and bare,
I find You breathing in my air.

You are the fire behind the frost,
The love that bears the soul’s deep cost.
No idol made of wood or pride
Can match the wound where You reside.

I’ve knelt before the gods of gain,
Before the whispers of my pain.
But now, with trembling lips, I say:
You are my dawn, my only day.

Let kingdoms rise and mountains fall,
Let oceans dry and night enthrall—
Still, I will sing, through grief and moan:
O God! Thou art my God alone.

For in Your eyes, my name is known,
Not as I’ve failed, but as I’m shown
A child, beloved, fully grown,
Returning, breathless, to Your throne.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other claim can shake this stone
Of faith that stands through storm and flood,
Rooted in eternal blood.

I found You not in lofty spires,
But in the crack of human wires—
In laughter choked, in silent cries,
In tear-streaked prayers beneath gray skies.

You dwell not just in hallowed hymns,
But in the pulse of wayward limbs
That stumble toward Your open door,
Seeking what they sought before.

The world has many names to sell—
Success, and fame, and fleeting hell.
But only You can make me whole,
The anchor of my wayward soul.

So I will sing, though weak my voice,
I make my joy and grief Your choice.
No idol, past or yet unknown,
Shall steal You from Your rightful throne.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
I am not mine, but Yours, Your own.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
This breath, this blood, this marrow, bone—
All whisper back Your ancient name,
A fire no other can reclaim.

I walked where false lights softly gleamed,
Chasing the echo of a dream.
But You—You stormed the silent room,
And shattered every veil of gloom.

Not in the thunder, nor the flame,
But in the whisper, You became
The song beneath my every sigh,
The tear that taught me how to cry.

You are the wound, and You the balm,
The storm, and You the outstretched palm.
No other god has bled for me,
No other love could ever be
So fierce, so tender, so undone—
You are my battle, and my sun.

So let the stars forget their tune,
Let time dissolve beneath the moon.
I stand where grace has overthrown
All gods but You, my God alone.

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
This truth has turned my heart to stone,
Then cracked it wide with love so deep,
It wakes the soul from endless sleep.

I sought You in the mountain’s crest,
In oceans vast, in eagle’s nest.
But found You in the child’s soft plea,
In bread broken, in mercy.

You are not distant, cold, or high,
But close—beneath the cry, the sigh.
You dwell within the humble groan,
The widow’s light, the beggar’s tone.

The world has many gods to sell—
Wealth, power, tales of heaven and hell.
But only You have died to prove
That perfect love is crucified love.

So I renounce each lesser flame,
And bless Your ever-holy name.
No other voice has called me home—
O God! Thou art my God alone.

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other name has claimed my bone.
Not in the rush of fleeting years,
But in the hush, You calm my fears.

I’ve wandered long on foreign strands,
With borrowed gods and shifting sands.
But here, where silence starts to bloom,
You pierce the night with holy room.

You are the breath in every lung,
The thread within the poet’s tongue.
Not just the star, but starlight’s source,
The love that charts redemption’s course.

I’ve loved the shadow, not the flame,
Chased after every human name.
But now, with lips both cracked and true,
I lift my voice—I lift it to You.

Let empires fall and nations cease,

Still, I will sing, though all be gone:
O God! Thou art my God alone.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
This heart, once restless, now has known
The stillness where Your whispers start,
The quiet beat of love and art.

I’ve danced with shadows, called them light,
Slept through the vigil of the night.
But You—you woke me with a flame,
Not loud, but sure, and just the same.

You are the root beneath the tree,
The depth behind the shallow sea.
No idol made of word or wire
Can match the warmth of Your desire.

You do not shout, but gently call,
You break the night, yet keep it small.
In every wound, I feel Your hand,
In every loss, I understand:

That love is not in having, but
In being held, though torn and shut.
So I return, though bruised and prone—
O God! Thou art my God alone.

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
In twilight's hush where echoes sleep,
A silver thread begins to creep—
Not time, but memory’s fragile seam,
Unraveling life like a whispered dream.

Rewind the breath that once took flight,
The stumble forward into night,
And in reverse, the stars align
To trace the shape of what was mine.

The laughter lost in crowded rooms,
The scent of rain on summer blooms,
The hand I dropped too soon, too fast,
Now drifts back through the ages past.

I watch my choices, slow and wide,
Like rivers flowing in reverse tide,
Each sorrow, joy, a mirrored face
Reflected now with gentler grace.

No blame, just wonder, soft and deep,
For wounds that time could never keep,
For love that burned though never claimed,
For words unsaid, now softly named.

So rewind life and remember me—
Not as I was, but how I'd be
If every turn, each fateful bend,
Could start again, and I attend.

But here I stand, in present haze,
With backward gaze and future daze,
And all I own is now, and then—
Two worlds that meet, and meet again.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

instance_metrics.response:
Rewind the film of years gone by,
Let silent frames replay the sky
That watched me stumble, rise, and fall,
And catch the moments meant for all.

Not just the milestones carved in stone,
But glances shared, and laughs full-grown,
A child’s hand within my own,
The seeds of love I never sown.

Let time reverse its steady beat,
Unwrite the lies and taste the sweet
Of honest words I failed to speak,
The strength I had, but would not seek.

Rewind the pain, the pride, the fear,
The wasted days, the deafened ear,
And in that loop, let wisdom bloom—
A second chance to leave the gloom.

Remember how the sunlight kissed
The morning I dismissed with mist,
How kindness wore a quiet face,
And left without a backward trace.

Now memory flows like backward rain,
Each drop a truth I couldn’t name,
And in the echo, soft and clear,
I hear the voice I used to hear—

The younger me, both bold and blind,
Still seeking peace of heart and mind.
So rewind life, and let me stand
With open soul and lifted hand.

For though I can’t retrace each mile,
I’ll honor every pause and smile,
And walk ahead with clearer sight,
Born from the gift of backward light.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

instance_metrics.response:
Rewind life and remember the hush before the cry,
the breath before the first lie,
the step before the fall.

Go back to where the pavement cracked
under the weight of choices packed
in satchels meant for play.

Rewind the clock not to erase,
but to retrace the quiet grace
of a mother’s lullaby,
a father’s laugh beneath the sky,
a friend who knew your silence spoke
before the world laid on its yoke.

Remember how the stars once felt—
not distant, cold, or strictly held
by laws of physics and of dust,
but kin, as if in them we must
have lived before the womb’s release,
and they still whisper hints of peace.

Rewind the years, not to amend,
but to attend, to comprehend
the child still crouched in shadowed rooms,
still humming tunes from vanished tunes.

Let memory flow in reverse,
like tides that cleanse instead of curse,
and let the past, once sharp with blame,
dissolve into a gentler flame—
not fire, but candle—warm and low,
illuminating what we know:

We were always trying,
always flying,
always breaking, always whole.

So rewind life, and let the soul
remember not the end, the fight,
but every spark before the night.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

instance_metrics.response:
Rewind the reel, the grainy past,
where shadows move too swift to last,
and every frame, a silent plea—
return, return, and let me see.

Not glory, not the grand displays,
but stolen glances, lost in days:
the way your hair caught afternoon light,
the dog who waited every night,
the book I read beneath the tree,
the dream I had of being free.

Rewind the sound, the muted tracks,
the things I said, the things I lacked—
the "I love you" I left unsung,
the battles fought, the songs unsung.

Let time contract, a breathing sphere,
and pull me close, dispel the fear
that all is lost, that none recall
the way we danced before the fall.

Remember how the world once bloomed
in hues no filter can assume?
The scent of bread, the rain’s first drum,
the silence when the music’s done.

Rewind life—not to rewrite,
but to re-feel the soft moonlight
that kissed my cheek on summer eves,
the hand that held me, not as keeps,
but as a bridge from then to now,
a vow I didn’t know I’d vow.

And in this loop, I do not flee,
but learn to see, and simply be.
For memory, when gently spun,
is not the end—it is the one
true thread that weaves through loss and gain,
and whispers: live, and live again.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

instance_metrics.response:
Imagine time as tangled thread,
a tapestry half-living, half-dead,
where every knot is pain or grace,
and every color has its place.

Now pull it back, undo the weave,
let moments rise from what we leave,
not to erase, but to recall
the quietest voice that meant it all.

Rewind life and remember the dawn
when hope was thin but still drawn
across the sky like fragile lace,
before the world set such a pace.

Remember how the leaves would spin
in autumn winds, a fleeting din,
and how you swore you’d never change,
though change was all you’d ever known.

Go back to birthdays, unadorned,
when joy came simple, unperformed,
when hugs were long and questions deep,
and promises were yours to keep.

Rewind the tears you wouldn’t show,
the nights you whispered, "I don’t know," 
the times you stood and turned away,
afraid of what the light might say.

Now memory flows like backward rain,
washing the rust from love’s old chain,
and in its fall, a truth takes form—
you were not broken, only warm,
with cracks that let the starlight through,
with wounds that shaped the whole of you.

So rewind, not to start anew,
but to reclaim the you that’s true,
the one who laughed, who dared, who wept,
who loved, though love was not always kept.

And when the film returns to now,
carry that past upon your brow—
not as a weight, but as a flame,
that whispers your forgotten name.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

instance_metrics.response:
Rewind the hours, grain by grain,
turn back the tide, release the chain
that binds us to the forward rush
of moments lost, of silent hush.

Not to escape, nor to deny,
but to relearn the reasons why
I laughed, I wept, I turned away,
and missed the dawn of every day.

Remember how the coffee steamed
while silence hummed, a dream half-dreamed?
The cat that curled upon the chair,
the book left open in the air?

Rewind the call I didn’t make,
the love I feared, the risks I’d fake,
the times I wore a face of stone,
while deep inside, I stood alone.

Let memory dance in backward flame,
reclaim the joy without a name,
the child who drew upon the wall,
the teen who feared a coming fall.

Remember how the stars would speak
in languages too soft, too weak
for ears grown dull with daily noise—
now hear them sing with quiet poise.

Rewind life and remember touch:
the hand, the kiss, the morning clutch,
the father’s arm, the mother’s song,
the place where I belonged.

And though I cannot stay in past,
nor make the vanished moments last,
I’ll carry back a single spark—
the truth that shaped me, dark and stark:

I was always worthy, even then,
before the world said, "Try again."
So rewind, remember, then release—
and walk ahead with inner peace.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

instance_metrics.response:
Rewind the wind-up heart, the spring
that coiled too tight for anything
but forward motion, blind and fast,
where past became a shadow cast.

Now let it unwind, slow and deep,
let broken rhythms rise from sleep,
and in the hush, the backward spin,
let every loss be felt again.

Not to relive the sting, the cost,
but to reclaim what time has lost—
the name of that small mountain stream,
the color of a childhood dream,
the way my grandmother would pray,
her voice like dusk at close of day.

Rewind life and remember sound:
the train that passed on frozen ground,
the laughter tangled in the trees,
the hum of bees among the peas.

Remember how my brother smiled
when we were both still reconciled,
before the silence built its wall,
before we let the distance fall.

Let memory flow in reverse waves,
like ocean tides from hidden caves,
returning shells I failed to keep,
now washed in wisdom, soft and deep.

And in this loop, I do not seek
to change the path, or grow unique,
but only to acknowledge pain,
and love that bloomed, then died, in vain.

For every scar, a story lives,
every regret, a truth that gives.
So rewind life, and let me stand
with open heart and steady hand,
and whisper to the ghost of me:
"You did your best. Just let it be."
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

instance_metrics.response:
Rewind the breath, the step, the sigh,
let moments fold beneath the sky
like cranes of paper, light and thin,

instance_metrics.response:
People are happy when the morning spills gold through the blinds, 
when laughter drips like honey from the edges of silence. 
They are happy in the quiet rebellion of bare feet on warm pavement, 
in the way a dog wags its whole body at reunion. 
Happy in the steam rising from a chipped mug, 
in the hum of a refrigerator at 2 a.m., 
when someone remembers how you take your tea. 
It’s not always loud—this joy. 
Sometimes it’s the soft click of a door locking from the inside, 
knowing you’re safe, you’re home, you’re unbothered. 
People are happy in the pause between heartbeats, 
in the breath before saying ‘I love you’ aloud. 
In gardens they plant with hands caked in soil, 
in letters never sent but cherished all the same. 
They are happy when the world shrinks to a shared glance, 
to a song that plays too loudly in a tiny kitchen. 
Even in grief, happiness flickers—
a memory that makes you sob and smile at once. 
People are happy not because life is kind, 
but because they find pockets of light anyway, 
small rebellions against the dark, 
like fireflies in a jar, 
like hands held tightly in a storm, 
like a single daisy growing through cracked concrete.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

instance_metrics.response:
People are happy when the universe conspires in whispers—
a stranger’s smile, a sudden breeze in July, 
the way rain patters like Morse code on tin roofs. 
They are happy not in spite of chaos, but within it—
in tangled headphones, missed trains, 
and burnt toast kissed with jam. 
Joy hides in laundry piles and grocery lists, 
in the weight of a cat curled on your lap, 
in the ritual of folding laundry just so. 
They are happy when time slows: 
a grandfather’s story retold, 
the first bite of a peach in summer, 
the silence after snowfall. 
It’s in the mundane alchemy—
how a shared umbrella becomes a dance, 
how a wrong turn leads to a view that steals breath. 
People are happy when they forget to perform, 
when they laugh until tears blur the world, 
when they dance barefoot in kitchens 
with no audience but the moon. 
Happiness is not a destination, 
but a frequency—felt in the spine, 
in the hum of a bus engine, 
in the crinkle of eyes when truth is spoken. 
It’s fleeting, yes, but fierce—
like a dandelion cracking stone, 
like a lullaby sung off-key, 
like choosing, again and again, to believe 
that today, perhaps, the light is kind.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

instance_metrics.response:
People are happy when they forget to measure—
when minutes melt into the amber of late afternoons, 
when laughter bubbles up like spring water, unplanned. 
They are happy in the curl of a cat’s tail, 
in the crunch of autumn leaves under boots, 
in the scent of rain on hot pavement—petrichor and promise. 
They are happy when they are seen, 
not admired, not judged, but truly seen—
by a friend who knows your silence, 
by a child who offers a muddy flower. 
Happy in the rhythm of routine—
the click of a kettle, the turn of a page, 
the way the same stars blink above different cities. 
They are happy when they create: 
scrawling poems on napkins, 
singing off-key in the shower, 
dancing in pajamas at midnight. 
Joy blooms in imperfection—
a crooked painting, a lopsided cake, 
a story told with wild hands. 
People are happy when they surrender—
to grief, to love, to the absurdity of being alive. 
When they plant seeds knowing they may never see the bloom. 
When they hold hands across hospital rooms, 
whispering, 'We made it this far.' 
Happiness is not a crown, but a cloak—
worn threadbare, shared freely, 
wrapped around shoulders shivering in the dark. 
It is the quiet yes beneath all the noise, 
the hum beneath the storm, 
the dandelion growing through the sidewalk, 
unapologetic, golden, alive.

when the mind unclenches, 
when the heart remembers its own rhythm. 
They are happy in the cradle of ordinary moments: 
a shared umbrella in sudden rain, 
the first sip of tea before the world wakes, 
the purr of a cat curled in sunbeam. 
Happy when they are not needed, not wanted, just allowed—
to sit, to stare, to exist without reason. 
They are happy in the alchemy of presence—
how a walk becomes a pilgrimage, 
how a conversation turns into communion. 
In the way bread rises, slow and sure, 
in the crackle of fire in a small hearth. 
They are happy when they create for no one—
scrawling verses in margins, 
doodling faces in notebooks, 
singing lullabies to plants. 
Joy is not earned; it arrives—
like mail left on the porch, 
like a breeze through an open window. 
People are happy when they remember they are animals—
rooted in earth, drawn to light, 
needing touch, warmth, rest. 
When they dance with no mirror, 
weep with no shame, 
laugh until the lungs burn. 
They are happy in the in-between—
not arrival, not departure, but the journey, 
the breath, the pause, the yes. 
Happiness is a dandelion seed—
fragile, flying, 
landing where it will, 
becoming something green.

slanting gold through dusty windows, 
etching shadows on worn wood. 
They are happy in the crinkle of paper bags, 
in the clink of spoons in mugs, 
in the way a child’s drawing is taped to the fridge. 
Happy when they are interrupted—
by a phone call from an old friend, 
by a sudden rainbow after storm, 
by the urge to spin in circles under stars. 
They are happy in the ritual of return—
to a favorite bench, a familiar path, 
a recipe passed down in smudged handwriting. 
In the way a sweater fits just right, 
in the smell of old books, 
in the hum of a refrigerator at midnight. 
Joy lives in impermanence—
a firefly’s blink, a soap bubble’s shimmer,

when they lie in fields, 
counting clouds,

of grudges, of plans, of the need to be right.

like breathing,

like choosing, again and again,

It seems like light years ago, but I still dream.

When I look up and see the past

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A quiet storm, a sky’s soft lover.
It kissed the graves, the rooftops, stones,
And turned the thorns to crystal thrones.
A child looked out with wide-eyed grace,
And saw the world in a new face.
"The snow," she said, "is God’s own pen—
Rewriting wrongs and healing men."
And in her words, the truth took cover—
It snowed and snowed, the whole world over.

and carved a world of its own.
Now silence laps at edges dry,
a whisper where waves once roared.
The heron stands in brittle sky,
its shadow stretched, ignored.

Dragonflies that skimmed the glass
now tumble through dusty air.
No ripple greets the sun’s harsh pass,
no silver fish dart there.
The willows weep in skeletal grace,
their roots clawing for what’s been lost.
Time has scrawled a barren face
on what was once a water’s boast.

Yet in one shallow, trembling round,
a minnow flicks, a pulse, a spark.
Life clings without a sound,
igniting darkness in the dark.
Oh, dwindling pool, so thin, so small—
you hold the echo of the fall,
and in your depths, a future calls.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
like eyes half-open, glazed with heat,
or maps of grief the land has gained,
or wounds from which no blood will meet.

No minnows flash, no currents glide,
no lilies bow to morning’s kiss.
The river’s pulse has long since died,
and thirst has swallowed every bliss.

Yet in one pool, a beetle rows
across a sea of shrinking glass.
It does not know the world now slows,
only that motion must amass.

Another holds a single stone,
still damp where water lingered last.
A child once placed it, all alone,
before the future turned so vast.

These pools—like prayers without a tongue—
still whisper songs the rain once knew.
They are the last notes, faintly sung,
of what the sky forgot to do.

And when they vanish, one by one,
the earth will carry their soft tune.
For even when the race is run,
the memory of water blooms in June.

Before me stands I see, a shadow carved from light,

I blink, yet still it stares, with eyes I’ve never met,
Reciting lines my soul once wrote, but can’t recall as debt.
It lifts a hand, I do the same—yet lag in time,
As if my will is second to its rhythm and its rhyme.

It speaks in silences, in breaths I fail to make,
A symphony of absence, every note a choice I’d break.
It knows the names I buried, the dreams I left to fade,
The love I turned to metaphor, the promises unmade.

And still it stands, not judging, not demanding space,
But holding up a sky I’ve cracked and cannot now replace.
Before me stands I see—not foe, nor friend, nor guide—
But all I am, and all I’m not, reflected deep inside.
